title: When AAA Means Something Different in Chinese
summary: Defaults by several companies owned by local governments in China have helped send AAA yields sharply higher. When is a AAA-rated asset not worth very much? In 2008 the answer turned out to be, when the asset is a mortgage-backed security declared AAA by a U.S. ratings company. This year the answer could be, when the issuer is a Chinese state-owned enterprise, and the AAA is applied by a Chinese ratings company.

title: 'Wonder Woman 1984' to Be Released on HBO Max and in Theaters Christmas Day
summary: WarnerMedia looks to use superhero sequel to promote HBO Max as theatrical attendance hits historic lows. AT&T Inc.'s Warner Bros. said Wednesday it will debut its highly anticipated "Wonder Woman" sequel simultaneously in theaters and on the HBO Max streaming service on Christmas Day. The move responds to both the crisis facing the movie business due to Covid-19 and the company's desire to attract consumers to its new digital platform.

title: U.S. Judge Agrees to Dismiss Case Against Mexico Ex-Defense Minister
summary: Court grants request motivated by foreign-policy concerns and driven by Attorney General William Barr. Mexico's former defense minister arrived back in the country Wednesday night after a U.S. judge dismissed drug-trafficking and corruption charges against him at the request of U.S. prosecutors, who said the unusual move was motivated by foreign-policy concerns and driven by Attorney General William Barr.

title: Ahold Delhaize Buys Majority of Delivery Company FreshDirect
summary: Deal gives owner of Food Lion and Stop & Shop a bigger presence on East Coast. The owner of supermarkets including Giant and Stop & Shop said it would acquire a majority stake in grocery delivery company Fresh Direct LLC, expanding its U.S. presence as online ordering has boomed during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Cyber Official's Ouster Tests Government Relations With Private Sector
summary: Lawmakers and executives fear Chris Krebs's firing will spark distrust from industry. Chris Krebs was widely credited with forging ties between the government and the private sector during his two-year tenure as director of the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency. Those ties are now under threat after he was fired Tuesday by President Trump, lawmakers and business executives say.

title: How Companies Are Dealing with Employee Burnout During the Pandemic
summary: Employers are shifting office culture to be more empathetic and are providing additional benefits to help employees cope. As the pandemic continues, many remote employees are reporting feelings of depression and anxiety. To respond to this need, companies are adapting policies and rushing to roll out benefits to head off a surge of employee distress.

title: Nvidia Was a Bit Too Amped Up
summary: Booming growth for gaming, data center processors come after stock tops record valuation. Sometimes playing even a perfect game isn't enough.

title: Nvidia Benefits From Sustained Remote Work, Videogaming Demand
summary: Graphics-chip maker 'is firing on all cylinders,' CEO says. Graphics-chip maker Nvidia Corp. is seeing no immediate letup in pandemic-era demand in home computing, videogaming and the use of its chips in big data centers, projecting this quarter to top the record sales it just posted.

title: Owner of Bath & Body Works, Victoria's Secret Gets Pandemic Lift
summary: L Brands posts a profit as company's total sales rise 14%, although lingerie brand continues to slump. Bath & Body Works posted a 55% jump in quarterly sales as the coronavirus fueled demand for soap and hand sanitizer, helping its parent company offset another quarter of declining sales at its Victoria's Secret lingerie brand.

title: Obama Memoir Sells More Than 887,000 Copies on First Day
summary: 'A Promised Land' logs highest opening-day sales of any Penguin Random House title. Former President Barack Obama's memoir sold more than 887,000 copies on Tuesday, a sizzling debut that publisher Penguin Random House said marked the largest first-day sales for any book it had ever published.

title: Some GOP Lawmakers Voice Frustration With Trump
summary: Congress grapples with pandemic relief, deal to fund government as president continues to challenge election results, fires cybersecurity official. WASHINGTON-President Trump's continued election challenges and late-night firing of a homeland-security official fueled frustration among some Republicans on Capitol Hill, where tensions are already high over the partisan deadlock on coronavirus aid and efforts to keep the government funded.

title: Georgia Secretary of State Says Biden Likely to Maintain Lead After Recount
summary: President-elect is ahead by 12,781 votes in state; audit results expected Thursday. Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger said Wednesday he doesn't expect the state's hand recount of presidential votes will reverse President-elect Joe Biden's lead there.

title: Thank You for Voting and Get Out
summary: Progressives help Democrats and get only ingratitude.. 'Thank you and get out and please come again," Apu, the canceled convenience store owner from "The Simpsons," tells a departing customer. The Democratic Party has a similar attitude toward progressives: They need our business but they don't want us around. This year establishment centrists have raised ingratitude to a high art since Joe Biden won the election without coattails.

title: Biden Should Impose Conditions on Rejoining WHO
summary: Insist that its pro-Beijing director resign, and that the organization readmit Taiwan as an observer.. Joe Biden says he'll take the U.S. back into the World Health Organization on his first day in office, reversing the withdrawal President Trump began in July. That would be a mistake. The coronavirus pandemic revealed the WHO as an agency ruinously in thrall to China. Rushing back in would reinforce this problem, not solve it.

title: How Republicans Kept Texas Red
summary: Democrats seemed to do everything right, but the GOP quietly carried the day.. Democrats seemed to do everything right to turn Texas blue this year. Joe Biden won 5,211,406 votes, 1.3 million more than Hillary Clinton in 2016 and 1.9 million more than President Obama in 2012. The Democrats' Senate candidate this year, M.J. Hegar, received the second-highest vote total ever for a Democrat in Texas: 4,844,433.

title: Hey, Trumpians, Cheer Up!
summary: At the risk of arousing the dark side, 2020's election results are reason for conservative optimism.. Pessimism is to conservative politics what pumpkin pie is to Thanksgiving: It's always on the table. Not long ago about this time of year, liberals would post articles with titles such as, "How to talk to your Uncle Jim at Thanksgiving." Those pieces had one valid premise-that Uncle Jim would say over his turkey that the world is going to hell, yet again. And on the evidence around some tables, Uncle Jim was right.

title: 'I Marched With Patton' Review: From a Soldier's Point of View
summary: The fear and the sorrow of being a young, untried, unworldly American sent overseas to ﬁght the Nazis during World War II.. Most of the new material about World War II in the past 30 years has come from two primary sources: the Russian and Eastern European archives opened since the fall of the Berlin Wall, and the personal diaries of veterans who had long remained silent but lately felt compelled to share what they had done and, more important, what they had seen during the biggest event of their lives. "I Marched With Patton," the remembrances of Oklahoma native and Third Army Artilleryman Frank Sisson-transcribed and augmented by the writer Robert L. Wise-is clearly of the latter. Mr. Wise has done an able job of organizing Mr. Sisson's account into a memoir that's full of the good and bad of war-families torn apart, laughing comrades remembered -making this well worth the read.

title: Notable & Quotable: Gov. Gavin Newsom
summary: 'We're all human. We all fall short sometimes.'. California Gov. Gavin Newsom in a Nov. 17 video:

title: Gretchen Whitmer Strikes Again
summary: Restaurants sue over Michigan's rule by emergency edict.. Rule by executive fiat in the states has become a hallmark of the pandemic, and Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer seems determined to push its limits. After a rebuke by the state Supreme Court, the Democrat has found a new statutory justification to continue her arbitrary emergency rule of one.

title: Happy Birthday, Joe
summary: Here's to good health, but a 78-year-old leader should be more transparent.. Seventy-eight candles on a birthday cake is an achievement in longevity for anyone, and Joe Biden earns the flames-and-frosting trophy this Friday. As Mr. Biden and his partygoers prepare to take over the White House, here's a wish for four years of good health.

title: Amazon Shakes Up Health Care
summary: New competition for pharmacies could have big consumer benefits.. Amazon has driven innovation and competition across the retail industry from supermarkets to books. Now it's gunning for pharmacies, which could force healthy changes across America's sclerotic health-care system.

title: Will Boris Tax Britain to Death?
summary: Killing the economy is no way to pay for pandemic relief.. If you thought the coronavirus lockdowns were bad for economies, wait until you see how governments pay for their relief spending. The United Kingdom is offering an early glimpse, and the results aren't pretty.

title: Hurricane Iota Leaves Destruction in Nicaragua
summary: At least 16 people are dead; rains bring flooding and risk of mudslides to the country and neighboring Honduras. MEXICO CITY-Hurricane Iota left a trail of destruction and at least 16 people dead in Nicaragua, while bringing more flooding, deaths and misery to neighboring Honduras in a region still reeling from Hurricane Eta two weeks ago.

title: FDA Clears First Covid-19 Test Performed Fully at Home
summary: U.S. regulator's authorization is a long-awaited step for diagnostic testing, but initial supplies will be limited. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has cleared the first Covid-19 test that people can take at home by themselves and get results without the help of a lab, a long-awaited step.

title: About Those Trump Vaccine Predictions
summary: Do media "fact checkers" owe the President an apology?. "Public-private partnership" is usually a Beltway term for cronyism and the waste of taxpayer resources. But so far it's hard to argue with the results of the Trump administration's Operation Warp Speed to assist the development and distribution of medical innovations to address Covid-19. The rapid results must be especially striking to news consumers who were repeatedly told that the president was wrong in predicting quick development of a vaccine.

title: As Absentee Ballots Are Counted in New York, 'Red Mirage' Evaporates
summary: Absentee ballots in a series of competitive races put Democrats ahead of GOP challengers. Democratic state legislators are coming back from political death after the opening of absentee ballots in a series of competitive races put them ahead of GOP challengers.

title: Boeing 737 MAX Cleared to Fly Again, but Covid-19 Has Sapped Demand
summary: FAA's order following two fatal crashes removes a major obstacle as pandemic creates fresh problems. The U.S. on Wednesday approved Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX jets for passenger flights again after dual crashes took 346 lives, issuing a set of long-anticipated safety directives and notices to airlines globally that will help resolve the plane maker's biggest pre-pandemic crisis.

title: Apple Slashes App Store Fees for Smaller Developers
summary: Tech giant lowers its commission to 15% from 30% for some app makers, after criticism over its power in the Apple-device ecosystem. Apple Inc. is halving the commission it charges smaller developers that sell software through its App Store, a partial concession in its battle with critics over how it wields power in its digital ecosystem.

title: Fed's Williams Says Lack of Fiscal Aid Could Challenge Economy
summary: Fiscal aid has "been a critical part of why the economy has recovered as well as it has," said Mr. Williams at a virtual appearance with journalists. Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams said Wednesday that if elected leaders don't deliver new aid for the economy, the path of the recovery will likely be slower than if help were provided.

title: Masks Aren't Perfect but Help in Proper Use
summary: Today's IHME modeling shows that if 95% of U.S. residents were to wear masks when leaving home, we could prevent the deaths of tens of thousands of Americans over the winter months.. In "Case for Mask Mandate Rests on Bad Data" (op-ed, Nov. 12), Phillip W. Magness fundamentally misses the point of the Covid-19 forecasting conducted by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. His argument hinges on the mask-wearing rate we use to create Covid-19 projections. He is correct that our estimate of mask-wearing rates has increased as we have incorporated new data into our model. He is incorrect to suggest that this weakens the case for public policies that require masks. As a cheap, widely accessible, effective intervention, masks can and should be our first line of defense against the pandemic, which is rising to dangerous levels in many states across the country, threatening lives, jobs and businesses.

title: Bring Our Troops Home From Afghanistan
summary: I have lost close friends in Afghanistan. Every day I think of their widows and children left fatherless. They did their duty. Now it's time for our civilian leadership to do its duty and bring our troops home.. Regarding your editorial "Rush for the Afghan Exits?" (Nov. 16): I was a Marine fighter pilot who was one of the first to fight in the American Afghan war 19 years ago. I flew my first mission less than one month after the 9/11 attacks. Along with my fellow USS Theodore Roosevelt aviators we toppled the Taliban and decimated the al Qaeda leadership. I thought the war was near its end when our ship returned in the spring of 2002. Today, Americans are still on Afghanistan's soil.

title: Trump's Covid Policy Has Been Reasonable
summary: The president didn't undermine regulatory authorities working on the virus, he streamlined the regulatory process.. Prof. Howard Forman's recounting of how President Trump handled Covid-19 is some type of dystopian dream ("There Really Is No Biden Covid-19 Fairy Tale," Letters, Nov. 5). He states that the president didn't deliver testing or protective equipment, yet the U.S. has more tests per million than any country, and President Trump pushed U.S. companies to produce PPE when he found the Obama-Biden administration left the storage bin bare and let China produce almost all supplies. President Trump didn't warn about the virus? Did the professor miss the daily Covid briefings with health experts? And, the president didn't undermine regulatory authorities working on the virus, he streamlined the regulatory process.

title: Blue Peril Threatens Texas; Refugees, Not Missionaries
summary: Texas doesn't need more progressive Californians with savior complexes, determined to use government to right all perceived social wrongs.. Regarding Joe Lonsdale's "California, Love It and Leave It" (op-ed, Nov. 16): As a lifelong Texan who has worked all over the country and world, I applaud Mr. Lonsdale's decision to move his enterprise to Texas. Our state welcomes businesses, and people, with more open arms than almost anywhere else. Over the last 20 years, Texas has seen enormous growth and prosperity, and it appears that isn't going to change.

title: New York City's MTA Warns of Service Cuts for Subways, Buses
summary: More than 9,000 of the authority's 68,000 workers could lose their jobs, as the pandemic weighs heavily on ridership. Commuters could have to wait much longer for subways, buses and trains in 2021 as New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Wednesday outlined potential service cuts to plug a multibillion-dollar deficit caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Investors Bet Economic Recovery Won't Spark Jump in Inflation
summary: Covid-19's hit to economic growth is seen to be outweighing inflationary pressures, as investors question the timeline of vaccine developments. Optimism about Covid-19 vaccines is raising hopes the economy will recover faster than expected. Investors are betting a rebound won't come with a bout of inflation.

title: Stocks Fall as Investors Weigh Vaccines, Virus Restrictions
summary: Investors weigh benefits of a vaccine against the cost of new restrictions as Covid-19 cases rise. U.S. stocks slipped Wednesday as mounting coronavirus cases forced more parts of the country to impose restrictions meant to fight the spread of the virus.

title: Fannie, Freddie Should Hold $280 Billion in Capital, FHFA Says
summary: The decision is a key step in efforts to return the two companies to private ownership. WASHINGTON-Mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will have to hold hundreds of billions of dollars of capital to absorb possible losses, their federal regulator decided on Wednesday.

title: New York City Public Schools to Close Thursday, Mayor Says
summary: City's rate of Covid-19 cases rises above 3% threshold for shutting schools. New York City will temporarily close its public schools and switch to fully remote learning for its students because of a rising number of Covid-19 cases in the city, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Wednesday.

title: Millennials and Gen Z Are Rethinking the Value of A College Education
summary: Millennials are the most educated generation in U.S. history, but student debt and new models of education are making them reconsider the value of a traditional four-year degree. As millennials rethink the value of a college education, younger generations are turning towards apprenticeships and vocational schools to meet their education needs and avoid getting stuck with a large bill.

title: Mail Balloting Is Fueling Historic Early Voting in the 2020 Election
summary: Some states have already received more early ballots than they did in the 2016 presidential vote. Ahead of Election Day, many states are already seeing historic levels of early voting as people cast their ballots through the mail in the middle of a pandemic.

title: Permission Accomplished (Thursday Crossword, November 19)
Pompeo Says Easing Iran Sanctions Would Be 'Dangerous Choice'
summary: President-elect Biden has said he will rejoin the 2015 nuclear deal scuttled by the Trump administration, releasing Iran's economy from a crushing blacklist. WASHINGTON-Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Wednesday said that the unwinding of the U.S. sanctions regime against Iran would be "a dangerous choice," obliquely expressing concerns that the incoming Biden administration would ease the four-year economic pressure campaign.

title: Election 2020: Trump Campaign Lawsuits, Explained
summary: A state-by-state guide to Republican post-election litigation. President Trump and his allies have filed lawsuits alleging election irregularities or improper ballot-counting procedures in five states where President-elect Joe Biden leads.

title: The Future of Kitchen Design Is Hands-Free and Smartphone-Activated
summary: Resume Subscription. Douglas Gilman put a new designer kitchen in his Manhattan apartment last year with entertaining in mind. He placed the sleek marble-accented Dada kitchen, from Italy's Molteni&C, at the center of the airy 2,800-square-foot home that he created from combining two adjacent units in a former West Village printing house. He figured it would give him easier access to his guests.

title: Norwegian Air Shuttle Files for Bankruptcy Protection
summary: Trans-Atlantic shuttle pioneered the Europe-U.S. budget market, racking up debt-then the pandemic struck. Norwegian Air Shuttle AS A filed for bankruptcy protection for two of its core units, marking Europe's biggest airline casualty yet from the pandemic.

title: A Los Angeles Mall Gets Snarled in Charged Debate Over Local Ownership
summary: Resume Subscription. The once-grand Baldwin Hills Crenshaw Plaza mall in Los Angeles seemed like a prime target for investors. That was before it got caught up in a combustible debate over local ownership, race and economic development.

title: Cultural Heritage in the Crosshairs Once More
summary: The resolution to the conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan leaves irreplaceable treasures in harm's way.. Active combat in the 2020 Azerbaijani war against Nagorno-Karabakh (known as Artsakh to Armenians) may have recently ended, but Azeri aggression against the rich and irreplaceable cultural heritage of its indigenous Armenian people has only just begun.

title: A Phoenix Home That Lets Apps Do the Work
summary: Dean and Angela Heckler use technology for everything from coffee-making to piano-playing. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'Mank' Is David Fincher's Movie About 'Citizen Kane.' But Other Legends Are Off Limits.
summary: Films about 'The Godfather' and 'Chinatown' are in the works, but movies about movies are tricky affairs in Hollywood. What does Hollywood do with a great movie? It makes a movie about it.

title: Maersk Line Expects Trade Rebound in 2021
summary: The world's biggest container carrier saw profits soar 83% in the third quarter on recovering volumes, rising freight rates. Danish shipping and logistics giant A.P. Moeller-Maersk A/S expects that the global container market could expand by up to 5% in 2021 in a rebound from the pandemic-driven hit to trade in the first half of this year.

title: Judge in Google Antitrust Case Eager to Set Initial Schedule
summary: Government signals it has over 100 potential witnesses; Google says it needs information on investigation quickly. WASHINGTON-The judge overseeing the Justice Department's antitrust lawsuit against Google said he hoped to set an initial schedule for the case in December, while a government lawyer indicated the department had more than 100 potential witnesses.

title: Pandemic Pressures Boy Scouts, Already Facing Sex-Abuse Claims Avalanche
summary: Revenue is down as the Boy Scouts seek to pay 95,000 sexual-abuse damage claims. Between Covid-19 pressures and more than 95,000 sexual-abuse claims, the survival of the Boy Scouts of America is on the line in bankruptcy court, lawyers for the national youth group said Wednesday.

title: Army to Weigh Upgrading Less-Than-Honorable Discharges
summary: Class-action settlement could give thousands of veterans expanded access to federal and state benefits. The Army will reconsider thousands of cases of soldiers who left the service under less-than-honorable conditions, part of a sweeping class-action settlement announced Wednesday that could allow for expanded access to federal and state veterans benefits.

title: Pelosi Backed by House Democrats to Serve Fourth Term as Speaker
summary: Hoyer, Clyburn and Jeffries also are expected to remain in current leadership positions. WASHINGTON-House Democrats backed Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday for another term as speaker, after a tumultuous two years in which she helmed the party's efforts to remove President Trump from office but lost seats in the recent election.

title: As New York Real Estate Emerges From Covid Crisis, Townhouses Come Out on Top
summary: Single-family homes in the city are outperforming co-ops and condos, as more buyers seek out space and privacy. Townhouses have long been the unwanted stepchild of the Manhattan luxury market, as wealthy buyers snatched up condos in the newly built high-rises increasingly crowding the skyline.

title: T.J. Maxx Parent Launches Online Platform as Coronavirus Persists
summary: TJX Cos. to launch HomeGoods e-commerce platform as shoppers remain reluctant to visit stores in pandemic. The owner of T.J. Maxx said it would launch an e-commerce platform for its HomeGoods home-and-furniture chain in the second half of 2021, changing course from earlier in the pandemic when it resisted an industrywide push to ramp up online sales.

title: Tempting New York Townhouses Amid a Pandemic
summary: With Covid-19 cases raging, some buyers are turning towards single-family living.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Chinese Covid Vaccine Gives Scientists Pause Over Antibody Levels
summary: Sinovac's vaccine candidate induced lower level of antibodies compared with patients previously infected, though that may say little about ultimate efficacy. A leading Covid-19 vaccine under development in China showed inconclusive results about its level of protection, although scientists remain optimistic that the candidate can be among a roster of effective vaccines used to fight the pandemic.

title: Trump Administration Can't Immediately Expel Migrant Children Under Pandemic Order, Judge Rules
summary: U.S. government said March CDC measure was intended to keep coronavirus from spreading in immigrant detention centers. A federal judge in Washington, D.C., ruled on Wednesday that the Trump administration couldn't immediately expel unaccompanied immigrant children who cross the southern border illegally and deny them a chance to request asylum under a public-health emergency the government declared in March.

title: Ralph Lauren's Polo Player Goes Scannable, AR for the Holidays
summary: In a deal with Snapchat, the pony and its rider will lead shoppers to an animated, augmented-reality ribbon they can take a selfie with. Ralph Lauren Corp. is introducing several new ways for consumers to shop its products this holiday season, including making its polo player and pony logo a scannable experience using Snap Inc. technology.

title: TikTok Teens Follow New Stars: Senior Citizens
summary: Older users are in the minority on the social-media app, but they are finding that their videos are a hit with younger generations; 'The young people want me to be their grandpa.'. Stephen Austin, 82, became a TikTok star earlier this year after he filmed a video of himself cooking at his senior living home near Fort Worth, Texas.

title: Boeing Must Emerge Smarter From 737 MAX Grounding
summary: The aerospace giant needs to find a balance between heeding its bean counters and engineers. A dark chapter in Boeing 's history can finally be closed. The moral is that business works best when finance and technology are in creative tension.

title: In Defense of Unpopular Clients-and Liberty
summary: Attacks on Trump's lawyers echo those against us for representing Guantanamo detainees. Both are wrong.. President Trump's re-election campaign and its supporters have filed lawsuits attempting to overturn the election results. Anti-Trump groups such as the Lincoln Project have sought to pressure the powerhouse law firms of Jones Day and Porter Wright to abandon the cases, in part by shaming their clients. The effort appears to have borne fruit: The latter firm withdrew from a case; the former said it wouldn't get involved with further election litigation.

title: Legal Drugs Are Fashionable-and Treacherous for Children
summary: When kids have to be put in foster care, parental substance abuse is usually the underlying reason.. The U.S. election didn't produce a blue wave or a red wave, but some are celebrating a green wave as voters in Arizona, Montana, New Jersey and South Dakota approved the legalization of recreational marijuana. Meanwhile, Oregonians decriminalized the possession of small amounts of harder drugs, including cocaine, heroin and methamphetamines. "Drugs, once thought to be the scourge of a healthy society, are getting public recognition as a part of American life," the New York Times gushed.

title: Market's Vaccine Euphoria Was Bad News for Momentum Funds
summary: For some trend-following investors, the recent abrupt market reversal inflicted pain. An abrupt reversal in many of this year's most-persistent market trends has hurt a cluster of computer-driven funds.

title: 'The Anonymous Lover' and 'Dido and Aeneas' Reviews: A Rediscovery and a Rehash
summary: A filmed production from the Los Angeles Opera spotlights the work of an 18th-century Black composer; the Boston Camerata offers a clumsy filmed staging of the Purcell classic..

title: Pfizer Says Covid-19 Vaccine Is 95% Effective in Final Data, Will Seek Authorization
summary: Shot could be on track to go into distribution by the end of the year if health regulators permit. Pfizer Inc. said it will ask health regulators to authorize its experimental Covid-19 vaccine within days, after reporting the shot was 95% effective in its pivotal study and showed signs of being safe.

title: Home Depot Starts Looking Better Equipped Than Lowe's
summary: Lowe's had a competitive advantage over Home Depot during the pandemic but the tables could turn. While both Home Depot and Lowe's were clear retail winners this year, the latter has arguably benefited more thanks to a less urban footprint and a higher proportion of do-it-yourself customers. That may be a winning formula today, but Home Depot is the one that seems poised for more upside post-pandemic.

title: Toilet Paper Déjà Vu All Over Again
summary: With Covid-19 cases spiking past levels seen in the worst days of the spring, another feature of that dark period is returning: toilet paper shortages. With U.S. Covid-19 deaths surging to levels not seen since the spring, a reminder of that bleak season is cropping up for anyone who has visited a supermarket this week: toilet paper shortages.

title: 'Devils' Combines Patrick Dempsey and a Eurozone Conspiracy. How Did It End Up On the CW?
summary: The glossy TV series features murder, lust, and a Ferrari-driving protagonist in a conspiracy story about the European debt crisis. The glossy drama "Devils" uses a complex conspiracy story to say some things about real-life economic crises and the machinery of global finance.

title: GOP Report Urges Multilateral Approach to China
summary: Republicans on Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommend putting aside differences with Europe that have rankled ties. Republican lawmakers are pressing for a more multilateral approach to confronting China with expanded help from Europe, a strategy that dovetails with the view of the incoming Biden administration.

title: Target Maintains Its Torrid Pace
summary: Comparable sales jump more than 20% for a second straight quarter as retailer makes broad gains in market share. Target Corp. said sales rose steadily in its most recent quarter, as demand for household goods and home office supplies continued to grow during the pandemic, while shopping shifted online.

title: Apple's First Cut May Not Be the Deepest
summary: Halving App Store fees for smaller developers won't quiet the critics pushing for antitrust scrutiny. Apple Inc. was always going to need to buy its way out of its App Store jam. The question is whether its opening bid will suffice.

title: New Entrepreneurs Emerge From Wreck of Covid Economy
summary: Resume Subscription. The coronavirus destroyed jobs. It also created entrepreneurs.

title: Herman Miller's New Stores Let Consumers Test-Drive High-End Office Chairs
summary: Small experiential stores look to bridge e-commerce with furniture showrooms. Office furniture company Herman Miller Inc. is trying to expand further beyond selling large orders of expensive chairs to employers with a new bid for individual at-home workers.

title: Trade Restrictions Relax After Early Pandemic Surge
summary: After rushing to protect supplies of medical equipment early in the pandemic, many governments have eased barriers. A surge in new trade restrictions that began in 2017 has waned over the course of 2020, as governments eased some of the barriers they put up early in the coronavirus pandemic.

title: In Aspen, High End Meets High Altitude in an Art-Filled Mountain Home
summary: Resume Subscription. High tech goes high altitude in a minimalist Aspen mansion for art collectors Jeff and Rona Citrin, an empty-nester couple in their early 60s who divide their time between Manhattan and the Colorado mountain town.

title: A Minimalist Mountain Home Near Aspen
summary: Jeff and Rona Citrin filled their Colorado home with wall-to-wall art.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: LeBron James Is Toasting the Tequila Market
summary: The Lakers star adds to his investment portfolio with Lobos 1707, a new tequila and mezcal. Anything-even a glass of tap water-can taste spectacular if you're sipping it on a yacht.

title: In Minnesota and Beyond, 'Defund the Police' Weighed on Democrats
summary: Resume Subscription. MINNEAPOLIS-In the state where "defund the police" became a progressive rallying cry following the killing of George Floyd, the phrase is now being blamed for harming down-ballot Democrats both here and nationally after some suburban voters were repelled by the message.

title: China Shifted Some Borrowing to Companies as It Fought the Pandemic
summary: Corporate borrowing had moderated in China but rebounded this year, driving a surge in the country's debt-to-GDP ratio. A new report suggests Beijing has been successful in shifting some government borrowing to the corporate sector, as it has enlisted companies to help limit economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Thailand Protesters Call on Parliament to Make Democratic Overhaul
summary: Lawmakers voted to advance constitutional amendments, but demonstrators say they fall short of their demands.

title: Congo Is Free of Ebola for First Time in More Than Two Years
summary: Vast African nation defeats its latest outbreak using cold-chain storage to deploy vaccines, raising hopes it could distribute a future Covid-19 vaccine. The Democratic Republic of Congo declared an end to its latest Ebola outbreak after deploying vaccines to some of the world's most remote jungle communities, marking a victory for the vast central African nation after battling the highly contagious viral disease during a simultaneous coronavirus pandemic.

title: Pharmacies Can't Ignore Amazon Drug Threat
summary: Shares of CVS Health and Walgreens Boots Alliance plunged Tuesday after Amazon launched online prescription delivery service. Amazon . com, the boogeyman of retail, is stalking pharmacies now. Shareholders are rightly spooked.

title: PG&E Taps Michigan Utility Leader as Next CEO
summary: Patti Poppe, who heads CMS Energy, will become the permanent replacement for the man who oversaw PG&E's exit from bankruptcy. PG&E Corp. has chosen the head of a Michigan utility as its next chief executive as it works to improve the safety of its electric system and strengthen its business after sparking a series of deadly wildfires that pushed the company into bankruptcy.

title: Life Insurers' Road to Full Recovery Is Long
summary: Covid-19 vaccine news has boosted life-insurance stocks, but lingering mortality risk could limit gains. Life-insurance stocks have been the beneficiaries of a huge relief rally this month, thanks to positive vaccine news and a jump in U.S. Treasury yields. But it is too soon to declare them fully healed.

title: Qualcomm CFO Overhauls Revenue Metrics as Business Shifts
summary: The chip maker this month for the first time provided breakdowns for its automotive and Internet of Things businesses, among others. Qualcomm Inc. finance chief Akash Palkhiwala overhauled some of the chip giant's revenue disclosures in the latest quarter, a move intended to reveal changes in the company's business strategy to investors.

title: GM to Sell Car Insurance, Using Data on Your Driving to Set Prices
summary: The Detroit auto maker aims to leverage the reams of data generated by its cars to establish an auto-insurance business. General Motors Co. is launching a car-insurance business based on the idea its vehicles can remotely track drivers' behavior and set insurance rates accordingly.

title: How Covid-19 Could Change Workplace Technology
summary: Among the predictions: Tools to make it easier to work from home, new ways to measure performance and more virtual reality. The coronavirus pandemic is forcing changes in workplace technology-or accelerating changes already in place-that will continue long after an effective vaccine is produced.

title: The Key to Creating Virtual Conferences That Work
summary: As event planners and attendees have learned, you can't just duplicate a live event online. You need to rethink schedule, structure and content.. With conferences, retreats and in-person meetings rare these days, and likely to remain so for the foreseeable future, we have all discovered which kinds of face-to-face events can (or can't) transfer to the internet. It's already clear that a great virtual event takes more than a solid Wi-Fi connection and decent web conferencing software; it takes careful planning, effective facilitation and the right mix of channels.

title: The Man at the Center of Wirecard's Deal Machine
summary: Henry O'Sullivan, an outside adviser, was paid on 10 Wirecard deals, some of which are the focus of investigators trying to unravel the company's collapse. German prosecutors allege that Wirecard AG executives overpaid for a string of companies, causing massive losses to shareholders of the now disgraced financial-technology company.

title: Child Tax-Credit Expansion Gains Traction
summary: Proposal could unite anti-poverty Democrats with pro-family, low-tax Republicans. WASHINGTON-Backers of a major expansion to the child tax credit are increasingly optimistic about the anti-poverty proposal's chances in the next Congress, no matter which party controls the Senate.

title: New York City Hospitals Get Ready for Fresh Surge of Covid-19
summary: Administrators say their primary concerns are staffing and worker burnout. New York City area hospitals are preparing for a significant resurgence of Covid-19 patients, with staffing and worker burnout their primary concerns.

title: Inside Jennifer Lopez's Pop Culture Empire
summary: After an acclaimed role in 'Hustlers' and a showstopping performance at this year's Super Bowl, the star is back with new music and a new movie, 'Marry Me.' Next up, a beauty line and a plan to build her brand into a global business.. Jennifer Lopez is sitting at the table in her kitchen in Los Angeles, palm trees soaring outside the picture window behind her, and I'm in my kitchen in New York, and it only takes a second of getting the angles just so before it feels like we're both sitting in the same kitchen, across from each other, having a normal conversation. Once we're settled, I notice that Lopez is shuffling a stack of papers, like a lawyer who doesn't want to forget her talking points during a hearing.

title: Boeing, Pfizer, Lowe's: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Vaccine optimism tempered by Covid-19 disruption could spell a choppy day in stock markets Wednesday.. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Wednesday.

title: How Michaela Coel Turned Trauma Into Hope With 'I May Destroy You'
summary: With a risky new TV series about consent, the writer-director-actor-showrunner-executive producer is inspiring audiences and change in her industry. This past summer, while the world was engrossed in her show, I May Destroy You, Michaela Coel was in London doing puzzles. The first one she completed featured an hourglass with an adage about patience, courtesy of a care package from HBO, one of the co-developers of her series. Many of the jigsaw puzzles she did next were colors. "Loads of colors. Like, just colors," Coel, 33, says over Zoom. Shapes. Textures. Gradients. Zodiac signs. She recognized puzzling as a sort of displacement, a calming obsession after two years spent writing, producing, directing, running and starring in the most emotionally challenging television series of 2020. During a summer of stress amid a worldwide pandemic, a show about sexual assault was somehow comforting, in part because it proved the infinite possibilities of simply surviving.

title: Covid-Era Exhibits Promote Art as Therapy
summary: To soothe visitors unsettled by the pandemic, some museums are showing works that aim to foster calm and hope. As the coronavirus pandemic began to rage early this year, the Bass Museum of Art in Miami Beach had a problem. A planned exhibition-Abraham Cruzvillegas's "Hi, how are you, Gonzo?"-was interactive. "It was very touchy and germy," said Silvia Karman Cubiñá, the museum's executive director and chief curator. "It was not possible."

title: Finland and Norway Avoid Covid-19 Lockdowns but Keep the Virus At Bay
summary: Tight controls on travel and borders-and political consensus-helped the Nordic nations fight the pandemic. While the U.S. and Europe struggle to contain an autumn surge in coronavirus infections, two small nations are bucking the trend, keeping cases under control without stringent restrictions.

title: For Covid-19 Vaccine, South Korea Says It Can Wait Until the Price Is Right
summary: With virus largely controlled, Seoul isn't rushing to procure vaccines from Moderna or Pfizer, in contrast with the U.S. and Europe. SEOUL-As many countries jockey to get Covid-19 vaccines, South Korea is plotting a different course: It can wait.

title: Local Shoppers Are Luxury Brands' Hedge Against Covid-19
summary: In a reversal of long-term trends, sales to European and American consumers will be stronger than to the Chinese in 2020. With few tourists in cities such as Paris and New York this year, luxury brands have had to lean on local shoppers. Their appetite for expensive handbags and watches has been surprisingly strong-a comfort for investors as Covid-19 cases in the West continue to climb.

title: New York Hotel Owners to Pay $500 Million to Pandemic-Hit Workers
summary: Ruling represents largest hotel-employee payout ever awarded in New York City, hotel owners and union representatives said. New York City hotel owners have to pay more than $500 million to employees displaced by Covid-19, according to people familiar with an arbitrator's recent ruling, a victory for tens of thousands of unemployed workers and a fresh setback for cash-strapped property owners.

title: Duolingo Valued at $2.4 Billion in Fundraising Round
summary: Language-learning app is on track to double its annual revenue in 2020 to as much as $200 million. Duolingo Inc. raised new money in a fundraising round that values the fast-growing language-learning app maker at $2.4 billion.

title: The Undrafted, $100 Million NBA Player
summary: Fred VanVleet did not hear his name called on his NBA draft night. Now he's perhaps the most coveted free agent on the market.. Fred VanVleet didn't expect his party during the 2016 NBA draft would send hundreds of his family and friends home disappointed. That night was supposed to be the celebratory end of a grueling process in which he hopscotched the country for 18 workouts and job interviews in 30 days. He knew he was a likely second-round pick, but he still hoped that some team had become so enamored with him that he would be drafted earlier.

title: Africa's First Pandemic Default Tests New Effort to Ease Debt From China
summary: Effort to ensure that China and bondholders participate in debt restructurings could help resolve Zambia's default. A new framework to resolve debt crises in developing countries, meant to ensure that Chinese and private creditors share the burden of providing relief, faces a key test after Zambia became the first African nation to default during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Chinese EV Maker Nio Is Accelerating Too Fast
summary: The reviving electric-vehicle market has revved Nio back up, but investors are letting the adrenaline rush go to their heads. The year of the pandemic has been an annus horribilis for most of the world after a relatively strong 2018 and 2019. But for Chinese electric-vehicle maker Nio , 2020 has turned into a terrific year following a near-death experience in 2019.

title: How the Biden Administration Will Tackle Travel
summary: The incoming U.S. president and his team will have to make quick calls on safe flying during Covid, the health of the airline industry, high-speed rail and much more. To: The Incoming Secretary of Transportation

title: JD.com Boss Gets Big Options Awards Ahead of Unit Listing
summary: E-commerce group says options are reward and motivation for Richard Liu. Chinese e-commerce group JD.com Inc. gave billionaire boss Richard Liu options to buy 2% stakes in its health and logistics units, an award that could enable him to accumulate holdings worth more than $1 billion.

title: Doctors Apply Covid-19 Lessons Learned as Cases Surge
summary: Months of hospital experience, global research and drug trials are helping medical teams refine treatment. When a man in his 40s with Covid-19 and low oxygen saturation arrived at the Boston hospital where Brittany Bankhead-Kendall treated patients in April, he was quickly put on a ventilator, a standard first response at many American hospitals at the time.

title: Canadian-Danish Group Strikes $9.6 Billion Deal for U.K. Insurer RSA
summary: Agreement offers boost in confidence for deals involving British companies ahead of Brexit completion. A Canadian and Danish insurance consortium agreed Wednesday to buy the U.K.'s RSA Insurance Group PLC for £7.2 billion, equivalent to $9.6 billion, in a deal that would rank it among the biggest acquisitions of a British company so far this year.

title: Biden Names Senior White House Staff
summary: Some Pentagon officials said they would be willing to meet off site with members of Biden team should standoff extend into December. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden on Tuesday named several White House staff members amid a continued standoff with the Trump administration over cooperating with his transition effort.

title: Israel Hits Military Sites in Syria After Finding Explosives Along Border
summary: Iranian forces' headquarters in Syria was among the targets, says Israel. TEL AVIV-Israel's military said early Wednesday it struck Iranian and Syrian military targets in Syria after Iran-backed fighters placed improvised explosive devices on the fence separating Israel and Syria.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Apple Reaches $113 Million Settlement With States Over iPhone Battery Issues
summary: The battery problem has been the source of one of the most prominent legal challenges involving the iPhone since its 2007 debut. Apple Inc. has agreed to a $113 million settlement with more than 30 states that accused the iPhone maker of concealing issues with batteries by throttling phone performance with a software update in 2016.
